results.title: Simply making jewellery
results.creator_credit: International Film Foundation, Sam Bryan and Ting Barrow
results.brief_description: Patricia Meyerowitz of New York City shows how she creates unique items of jewellery using inexpensive objects found in hardware stores, art and garment supply stores and elsewhere.

results.title: Simplification
results.creator_credit: Nordisk Film Junior and Soren Melson
results.brief_description: Simplification in manufacturing and the consequent benefits to producer and consumer. How standardisation of sizes, reduction of the number of sizes and types of an article produced have resulted in smoother work flow, greater specialisation and reduced handling costs. Examples from the wood industry, where simplification has enabled well-designed furniture to be produced at very reasonable cost, while standard sizes of barrel staves and fruit and fish cases enable mills to use scrap wood and slack time knowing that the product can be readily sold as required. Stresses the relation between planned production, consumer needs and advertising. English soundtrack.

results.title: Simple seams
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sewing”.
Demonstrates the procedures for preparing plain seams with the edges pinked; edges overcast; edges stitched; edges bound; edges catch-stitched; and the edges top-stitched. In each case the procedure for pressing the seam is demonstrated.

results.title: Simple plants: the algae
results.brief_description: Illustrates typical forms of algae, explains their structure and traces their evolutionary development. Also shows reporductuve processes. From the series “Biology Program. Unit 2. Plant Life.”

results.title: Simple plants: Algae and fungi
results.brief_description: Descibes major characteristics of simple plants and shows how they differ from higher plants; shows their natural habitat; explains major differences between algae and fungi; and points out diverse human uses of algae and fungi.

results.title: Simple organisms: Bacteria (Revised)
results.brief_description: Looks at the discovery of bacteria and examines their structure and means of feeding. Binary fission and antibiotics are examined, as are some uses of bacteria, nitrogen fixing, cheese making and chemical manufacture.

results.title: Simple multicellular animals: sponges, coelenterates and flatworms
results.brief_description: Begins with a study of volvox and then moves to sponges, coelenterates and flatworms as examples of multicellular animals. Covers anatomy, nerve structure, fading strategies and reproduction. No other credits available.

results.title: Simple men
results.creator_credit: True Fiction Pictures, Ted Hope and Hal Hartley
results.brief_description: Two brothers are searching for their terrorist father who has escaped from goal. The trail leads them to a small town on Long Island where they meet a community of people who give them a refreshingly different view of their father. The ensuing complications between the brothers, as they battle to discover the truth of their family history, results in their confiding and falling in love with two very independent women. In order to defend their father’s honour, they all become involved in a battle with the police that leads to a surprising resolution. From this simple plot Hartley creates an eccentric film about history and relationships that challenges the viewer’s stereotypes of heterosexual romance. As is typical in Hartley’s work, the ensemble cast is universally excellent, including Martin Donovan, Robert Burke and Bill Sage. Special mention must go to Elina Lowensohn who plays a Romanian immigrant who falls in love with one of the brothers. The Godardian scene in which she leads a dance to Sonic Youth’s song “Cool Thing” is one of the film’s highlights. The musical score is excellent.
